comment.author: 16249407@N00
comment._content:
Nelson's Pillar was blown up by the IRA in 1966 no was was hurt in the explosion.
2 days later the Irish Army blew up the rest of the pillar and did more damage to O'Connell Street then the IRA did in the first explosion.

comment.author: 64848937@N00
comment._content: A great view of the main street in the city.  Apalling damage was done to the street as a result of the Rising of 1916 when a gunboat sailed up the Liffey to the Bridge and fired on the street.  The street was restored afterwards and today looks, if anything, more impressive.  Film of the Rising in 1916 shows new trees having been planted in the centre of the street and these were all removed in the past decade as the architects' department of Dublin City Council decided to 'improve' the street and rebrand it as a boulevard in the French style.  Dubliners were horrified at the loss of the mature London Plane trees which had housed a massive population of wagtails and other birds.  What is striking today in walking the street is the vast diversity of people from all parts of the world who now call Dublin home.
